Activity: Set up a test database environment to validate the new database schema. This environment should be isolated from the production environment to prevent any accidental data corruption.
Execute the DDL scripts in the test environment to create the new tables and table extensions. Verify that all objects are created successfully and that there are no errors.
Prepare test data for the new tables. This data should be representative of the real-world data that will be stored in the production environment.
Insert the test data into the new tables and verify that the data is stored correctly. Perform basic queries to test the relationships between the tables.
Conduct performance testing on the new tables and queries. Monitor query execution times and identify any potential bottlenecks.
Based on the performance testing results, fine-tune the database schema and indexing strategies as needed. Re-run the tests to verify the improvements.
Document the test results and any adjustments made to the database schema. Prepare a summary of the validation process for review.
Final review of the week's work. Ensure all documentation is complete and accurate. Prepare for the next steps, including planning the migration to the production environment.
